The kinetics of the ethyl acetate synthesis by direct addition of acetic acid to ethylene on an industrial silicotungstic acid catalyst have been acquired experimentally by systematically varying the operating conditions. This is essential to assess the effects of the operating conditions on reactant conversions, selectivity towards the main product ethyl acetate and side products, i.e. ethanol and diethyl ether. Conversions benefit from increasing reaction temperature and ethylene concentration and from reducing pressure, acetic acid and water concentrations. Higher acetic acid and lower water concentrations are advantageous for the ethyl acetate selectivity, which is not altered by temperature, pressure and ethylene concentration. Present work is the first publication of experimental kinetics data of this reaction on an industrial catalyst, which is essential to provide qualitative insights in the reaction kinetics, improve understanding and, hence, serve the optimization and innovation of ethyl acetate production plants that apply the direct addition technology. An important industrial scale process, where plant optimization is essential from both an economic and environmental point of view, is the production of ethyl acetate (EtOAc) [1,2]. Ethyl acetate is an organic solvent used in many applications, such as glues, surface coatings, thinners, paints, inks, nail polish removal products, and as a solvent in chemical and physical processes, e.g. decaffeinating coffee and tea, etc. In 2015, the annual world capacity of the solvent production amounted to 5.1 Mton, whereas the consumption was about 2.9 Mton. This demonstrates that the market is currently saturated, indicating that it is crucial for producers to reduce their operating costs to maintain and ideally improve their market shares [1,2]. Ethyl acetate can be produced from a number or chemicals, including ethylene (C2H4), ethanol (EtOH), acetic acid (AcOH), acetaldehyde (AcH) and other hydrocarbons or oxygenates, often by the aid of an acidic catalyst. Typically, ethyl acetate production, i.e. chemical reaction and separation, is quite energy intensive. The main production route for ethyl acetate is the liquid-phase acid-catalyzed esterification of ethanol and acetic acid, which results in the formation of water (H2O) as a side product. Here, the overall conversion is enhanced by removal of the side product via distillation. The ethanol availability and price as well as the necessity to use strong liquid acids as catalyst are major drawbacks of this route [1,3]. Ethyl acetate can be also synthesized from acetaldehyde via the Tishchenko reaction, an oxidation-reduction process in which alkoxide catalysts are often employed [4,5]. However, the higher cost of acetaldehyde as well as its toxicity compared to other raw materials, such as ethanol and ethylene, are troublesome [6,7]. Other potential routes for the synthesis of EtOAc are: i) transesterification of esters, e.g. polyvinyl acetate with ethanol to ethyl acetate and polyvinyl alcohol; ii) dehydrogenation of ethanol on a copper catalyst to yield ethyl acetate in the absence of acetic acid; and iii) hydrocarbon oxidation reactions [1]. Next to ethanol, ethylene can also be used as raw material to produce ethyl acetate, e.g. by direct addition of acetic acid to ethylene, catalyzed by strong solid acids, such heteropoly acids, acidic resins or zeolites [8,9]. The availability of an ethylene supply in certain geographical areas, e.g. the pipeline from Teesside to Saltend in the UK and the naphtha cracker in the Oita complex in Japan, eliminates large expenses for construction and operation of ethanol production plants. Hence, given the proper constraints, from an economic point of view, the direct addition route can be advantageous for the production of ethyl acetate [1,3,10,11]. The direct addition technology has been developed in the ‘90 s by BP Chemicals as the AdVanced Acetates by Direct Addition™ (AVADA™) process in the United Kingdom and developed by Showa Denko in Japan [8,10,12,13]. BP Chemicals’ AVADA™ process has been operated by INEOS since 2006 for which the production plant in Hull (UK) has a capacity of 340 kton a−1 ethyl acetate. Showa Denko operated a 50 kton a−1 ethyl acetate plant in Indonesia since the ‘90 s, which was shut down in 2015 due to rising material prices and the expansion of capacities of neighboring competitors [1,14]. In 2014, the company started a 100 kton a−1 ethyl acetate plant in Japan to better align with the sophisticated and diversified customer demands as well as to improve its status as stable supplier of high quality ethyl acetate [1,15]. Silica (SiO2) supported silicotungstic acid (STA, H4SiW12O40) is employed as catalyst in these continuous vapor phase processes. The reaction is typically performed at a temperature between 443 and 473 K, pressures around 0.8–1.4 MPa and molar ratio of C2H4:AcOH between 10 and 14 [8]. H2O is present in a concentration of 3–8 mol% in the feed, which results in the formation of oxygenates, primarily ethanol and diethyl ether (DEE) [8,16–18]. Five overall reactions between the reactants leading to the formation of the main products can be identified for the ethyl acetate synthesis by direct addition as visualized in Scheme 1. Reactions r1, r2 and r3 are direct additions of acetic acid, water and ethanol to ethylene and yield ethyl acetate, ethanol and diethyl ether respectively. Reaction r2 is also referred to as ethylene hydration. The esterification between acetic acid and ethanol to ethyl acetate and water is presented by r4, where the ethanol condensation or dehydration to diethyl ether is depicted by r5 [19–22]. Apart from ethyl acetate, ethanol and diethyl ether, other oxygenates, such as acetaldehyde, methyl ethyl ketone, hydrocarbons, mostly butenes, and various other alcohols, ethers, esters, aldehydes and ketones can be detected as minor components in the product stream [21,23]. It has been reported that protons as well as hydronium ions (H3O+) catalyze reactions on heteropoly acids by protonation of components and formation of intermediates, such as carbocations (e.g. ethyl cation) and alkoxides (e.g. ethoxide) [21,24–28]. The silicotungstic acid catalyst belongs to the class of heteropoly acid (HPA) catalysts. Each molecule consists of a relatively large anion (SiW12O40 4-) and four protons to compensate the charge balance, generating strong Brönsted acidity, because of the large anion size of heteropoly acids [29]. The protons act as the active sites for acid catalysis, which allow for protonation of reactants and formation of intermediates, such as carbocations and alkoxides [12,21–23,30]. Depending on the operating conditions, heteropoly acids can be highly hydrated and anions can link together in crystalline structures via protons and their hydration water in the form of hydronium or poly-hydrated hydronium ions ((H2O)xH+), for which heteropoly acids can take 20 up to 30 water molecules per anion [24]. Unlike other solid acids such as zeolites and ion exchange resins, heteropoly acids have distinct units that are, to a certain extent, flexible and mobile and can be penetrated and dissolved by ions and polar solvents. Moreover, it has been demonstrated that heteropoly acids can behave like a liquid solution due to the mobility of the heteropoly anions in solution, an uncommon phenomenon in heterogeneous catalysis, referred to as a ‘pseudo-liquid phase’ in which polar vapors can condense, as a result of capillary condensation, leading to expansion of the liquid solution [24,27,31–33]. It has been shown that the synthesis of ethyl acetate on supported STA catalysts proceeds at the outermost surface of the heteropoly acid structures. Hence, the presence of a support is essential to provide a high dispersion of the silicotungstic acid and, consequently, increase the surface area of the active phase [12,34]. Patents and publications reveal that the surface area of the silica used as support ranges from 150 to 400 m² g−1, the pore size and volume from 60 to 120 Å and from 0.3 to 1.8 mL g−1 respectively. The loading of the STA on the catalyst changes between 27.5 and 548 gSTA kgcat −1 [12,13,35,36]. Catalyst samples with constant surface area, pore size and volume and loading have been provided for the experimentation. As evident from the previous paragraphs, a lot of research has been conducted on the process as well as on the catalyst. However, to the best of our knowledge, the reaction kinetics have not been elaborated in detail, although this is very essential for future optimization of ethyl acetate production plants that apply the direct addition technology. Therefore, the present work aims at a detailed experimental kinetic study of the ethyl acetate synthesis by direct addition of AcOH to C2H4 on a commercial STA catalyst. Focus is given to the ethylene and acetic acid conversions as well as the selectivities and yields to the main products (ethyl acetate, ethanol and diethyl ether) as a function of the space time and operating conditions: temperature, pressure and feed composition. Attention is also paid to the net rates of formation for which apparent relationships were identified between the net rates of formation of ethanol and ethyl acetate and between ethanol and diethyl ether. We aim to gain insight in the reaction kinetics and to identify the key operating conditions that affect conversions and selectivities, which will serve as input for the future development of a kinetic model for the direct addition reaction. This kinetic model could then be utilized to improve ethyl acetate production processes, generate ideas for innovation and accordingly to reduce costs, waste and impact on environment and climate. 2 Procedures The following sections focus on the methods applied for the measurements and evaluation of the kinetic data, for the assessment of the intrinsic kinetics and for the calculation of the gas phase equilibrium composition. 2.1 Kinetics measurements The kinetic data were experimentally acquired using a fixed-bed plug flow bench scale reactor setup as visualized in Figure SI 1 of the Supporting Information (SI). The reactor is equipped with mass flow controllers (MFCs) and a High-Performance Liquid Chromatography pump (HPLC) to dose the gases (C2H4 and N2) and liquids (a mixture of H2O and AcOH), respectively. Heaters, thermocouples, a pneumatic needle valve, a pressure transmitter and controllers provide adequate temperature and pressure control for the reaction. The reactor effluent analysis was performed by gas chromatography (GC) for which an Unicam Thermo Onix ProGC+ and a Hewlett Packard 5890 Series II are used. The triple channel Unicam Thermo Onix ProGC+ operates two channels for product analyses. The first channel is used to separate the oxygenates on a CP-WAX (5.5 m x 0.32 mm × 1 µm) and a 52CB (50 m x 0.32 mm × 0.5 µm) column connected in series. Hydrogen gas (H2) is used as carrier with a flow of 5 mL min−1, the temperature of the column oven is ramped after 3.5 min from 40 to 140 °C at 12 °C min−1 and hold for 4 min. The channel is equipped with a split/splitless injector for which the split ratio equals 12. The components are quantified by a flame ionization detector (FID) for which the H2, air and make-up (N2) gas flow rates are 35, 350 and 60 mL min−1 respectively. The temperature of the detector and split/splitless injector are set at 300 and 200 °C respectively. N2, C2H4 and H2O are isothermally separated at 150 °C by a Hayesep S (1 m x 1/8″ OD (outer diameter)) and a Hayesep Q (4 m x 1/8″ OD) column connected in backflush configuration and are measured by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). H2 is used as carrier for which the flow equals 2.7 mL min−1, the reference gas is H2 with a flow of 13 mL min1 and the detector is operated at 180 °C. One channel of the double channel Hewlett Packard 5890 Series II is used to quantify hydrocarbons, except C2H4, which are separated on a backflush configuration of two KCl/Al2O3 columns (3 m and 50 m x 0.32 mm × 5 µm) operated at 25 psig carrier gas (H2) pressure, where the temperature of the column oven is ramped after 3 min from 60 to 190 °C at 15 °C min and hold for 8 min. The channel is equipped with an FID at 200 °C for which the H2 and air pressures equal 15 and 40 psig respectively. No make-up gas is used for this detector. The reactant responses were determined by injecting the reaction feed at reference conditions in the GC, while the product response were retrieved by injection of mixtures of oxygenates. The reference conditions are a relative space time ((W/F0)rel) ranging from 0.2 to 1.0, a temperature and pressure amounting to 442 K and 1.2 MPa, respectively. Moreover the feed flow rates were set such that the molar C2H4:AcOH:H2O:N2 feed ratio was 78.2:6.5:5.3:10.0. These operating conditions were chosen as the reference conditions and are similar to previous studies on this reaction and catalyst [8]. The relative space time (W/F0)rel is defined as the ratio of the space time of the experimental data point relative to the maximum space time applied in the entire campaign. The commercial silicotungstic acid catalyst was loaded into the catalyst bed, comprising 2 zones: i) a front bed of inert material at the inlet of the reactor tube to equilibrate temperature of the reactants and catalyst bed; and ii) the actual catalyst bed, a mixture of catalyst and inert material. The catalyst mass (W) was varied between 5 and 10∙10−3 kg, whereas the volumetric catalyst-to-inert dilution ratio (Vcat:Vinert) was changed between 1 and 3 m3:m3. Upon start-up, the operating conditions were set at a relative space time between 0.2 and 0.6, a temperature between 433 and 442 K, a pressure of 1.2 MPa and a molar C2H4:AcOH:H2O:N2O feed ratio of 78.2:6.5:5.3:10.0 for at least 5 h in order to stabilize the catalyst activity. Once the C2H4 and AcOH conversions were stable within 1% relative, the catalyst bedding period to remove the initial catalyst activity after re-catalyzation was considered complete. Subsequently, the operating conditions were changed and allowed for re-stabilization. When conditions were stable, i.e. the component flow rates at the outlet of the reactor did not change within ± 2%, the kinetic data was obtained by running 2–3 subsequent GC injections for which product flow rates were averaged and operating conditions were subsequently adjusted to another set. The maximum time on stream (TOS) reached during the experimental runs was 780 h. During the experimental campaign, temperature and pressure were varied as well as the concentrations of components in the feed. When a component’s feed concentration was varied, denoted as yC2H4 0 (mol%), yAcOH 0 (mol%) and yH2O 0 (mol%) for respectively C2H4, AcOH and H2O, the N2 feed concentration was changed as well such that the other components’ concentrations remain unchanged. The operating conditions applied for the data acquisition at steady state are summarized in Table 1. 2.2 Evaluation of the experimental data The reference experimental conditions were used to evaluate the catalyst activity at a given TOS, in terms of net rates of formation of EtOAc, EtOH and DEE, respectively REtOAc, REtOH and RDEE, via Eq. (1). As the catalytic activity continuously decreases with TOS, the net rates of formation were scaled relative to the minimum rates obtained during the entire experimental campaign, such that the experimental datapoints and observed effects of operating conditions on kinetics can be assessed at the same catalyst activity level. (1) R i = F i − F i 0 W In Eq. (1), Fi 0 and Fi (mol s−1) are the molar flow rates of the component at the inlet and outlet of the reactor, respectively. The net rates of formation of C2H4, AcOH and H2O are negative, because these components are consumed instead of formed. Based on Scheme 1, the net rates of formation are related to the reaction rates according to: (2) R C 2 H 4 = − ( r 1 + r 2 + r 3 ) R EtOAc = r 1 + r 4 R AcOH = − ( r 1 + r 4 ) R EtOH = r 2 − r 3 − r 4 − 2 r 5 R H 2 O = − ( r 2 − r 4 − r 5 ) R DEE = r 3 + r 5 Conversion of reactant i (xi,%) and selectivity to product j (Sj, mol%) are calculated according to Eqs. (3) and (4), respectively: (3) x i = F i 0 − F i F i 0 100 (4) S j = e j F j ∑ k e k F k 100 Where ej represents the stoichiometry number of species j, which accounts for the net number of C2H4 molecules consumed for the formation of the component, i.e. 1 for EtOAc and EtOH and 2 for DEE. Based on conversion of species i and selectivity to product j, the yield of the product (Yj, %) can be determined as follows: (5) Y j = x i S j The experimental data at varying temperatures allow to calculate apparent activation energies (Ea) of the net rates of formation according to the Arrhenius relationship, being the first term in the right hand side of Eq. (6), in which Rg is the universal gas constant (8.314 m3 Pa k −1 mol−1). Similarly, the datapoints at which the total pressure, C2H4, AcOH and H2O feed fractions are changed are used to assess the effects of these operating conditions on the net rates according to a power law type relationship as expressed by the other right hand side terms in Eq. (6), where ν, α, β and γ, are exponents. (6) R i ∼ exp − E a R g T P ν y C 2 H 4 0 α y AcOH 0 β y H 2 O 0 γ The experimental error as well as the 95% confidence intervals have been determined by performing repetition experiments at 434–442 K, 0.8–1.4 MPa and the molar C2H4:AcOH:H2O:N2 feed ratio equal to 78.2:6.5:5.3:10.0 for which the confidence intervals of the experiments with the highest experimental error are reported in this work (Section SI 2 of the SI). 2.3 Assessment of transport phenomena on kinetics Intrinsic kinetics can only be obtained when the experimental data is free from mass and heat transfer limitations. Moreover, the tubular reactor should be operated in plug flow regime in absence of flow maldistribution. To this extent, correlations have been used to estimate internal (ΔTint), external (ΔText), radial (ΔTrad) and axial temperature gradients (ΔTax) as well as the Carberry number (Ca) and Weiss modulus (Φ), which are measures for external and internal mass transfer limitation, respectively (Section SI 3 of the SI) [37]. Moreover, the catalyst particle diameter (dp, m) is compared to the reactor inner diameter (dt, m) and bed height (hbed, m). These parameters have been evaluated for the reference conditions (442 K, 1.2 MPa, C2H4:AcOH:H2O:N2 feed molar ratio = 78.2:6.5:5.3:10.0, (W/F0)rel = 0.5 and dp = 2.9∙10−3 m) and most severe conditions, i.e. at temperature equal to 463 K with identical pressure, feed composition, relative space time and catalyst diameter. External mass transfer limitations and the occurrence of plug flow regime have been investigated by performing experiments with different catalyst mass loaded to the reactor, i.e. 5–10∙10−3 kg at equal space time, a temperature of 442 and 463 K, 1.2 MPa pressure and the molar C2H4:AcOH:H2O:N2 feed ratio equal to 78.2:6.5:5.3:10.0 (Section SI 3 of the SI). Similarly, internal mass transfer limitations and the verification of plug flow regime have also been assessed experimentally by varying the catalyst particle between 0.5 and 2.9∙10−3 m at 442 and 463 K, 1.2 MPa and the molar C2H4:AcOH:H2O:N2 feed ratio equal to 78.2:6.5:5.3:10.0 (Section SI 3 of the SI). Absence of external and internal mass transfer limitations and the verification of plug flow regime can be verified by considering the net rates of formation of all species, which should remain constant with varying catalyst mass and particle diameter respectively. 2.4 Equilibrium calculations For a general reaction, i.e. A + B ⇌ C + D , the equilibrium coefficient (Keq) is determined by Eq. (SI 4) and (SI 5) in Section SI 4 of the SI for which the ASPEN database are consulted ( Table 2). The heat capacities are determined as a linear function of temperature (Table 2) by using the ASPEN database as well (Table 2). The fugacity of component i (fi, bara) is calculated via Eq. (8) as a function of the corresponding mole fraction (yi, -), fugacity coefficient (ϕi, -) and pressure (P, bara). The temperature, pressure and composition dependent fugacity coefficient is determined via the Hayden O′Connell equation of state for which the ASPEN database were consulted for the necessary parameters, i.e. critical temperatures, critical pressures, dipole moments, radii of gyration and association parameters. The equation of state is typically used when carboxylic acids are present in the gas phase, hence, the presence of AcOH and the gas phase nature of the process justify the selection [38,39]. (8) f i = y i ϕ i P The equilibrium composition of a mixture of C2H4, AcOH, H2O, EtOAc, EtOH, DEE and N2 can now be calculated by solving a system of 3 reaction equilibria and 3 mass balance equations, in which the 6 reacting components are involved, e.g. r1, r2 and r3 (Scheme 1), to the mole fractions of all components. 3 Results and discussion The assessment of the operating condition effects on kinetics are shown and discussed in the following sections, where the focus is given to conversions and selectivities. In addition to space time, temperature and pressure, also the effects of varying reactants’ concentrations in the feed on kinetics were investigated. 3.1 Evaluation of the experimental error The 95% confidence intervals of the C2H4 and AcOH conversion, EtOAc, EtOH and DEE selectivities and net rates of formation of the reactants and products for the experiments with the highest relative errors can be found in Table 3. The corresponding relative errors in C2H4 and AcOH conversions equal 7.3% and 7.4% respectively, whereas the maximum relative errors in selectivities to EtOAc, EtOH and DEE amounts to 0.4%, 5.7% and 20.9% respectively. The maximum relative errors in net rates of formation of C2H4, AcOH and H2O are 7.3%, 7.4% and 8.1% respectively, while the maximum relative errors are calculated to be 7.4%, 8.4% and 19.2% for the net rates of formation of EtOAc, EtOH and DEE respectively. Although the standard deviation of the DEE product flow rate is similar compared to the EtOH product flow rate, the higher error for the DEE selectivity and the corresponding net rate of formation compared to the conversions, other selectivities and rates stem from the low DEE product flow rate. 3.2 Assessment of transport phenomena on kinetics The calculated temperature gradients as well as the Carberry number and Weiss modulus are listed in Table 4. It can be seen that all temperature gradients are sufficiently small as well as the Carberry number. However, the Weiss modulus slightly exceeds its threshold value and, hence, mass transfer limitations cannot be entirely excluded at both temperatures. Furthermore, the ratio of the reactor inner diameter to the catalyst particle diameter is smaller compared to the criterium value, which might indicate maldistribution of flow and therefore potentially distorting plug flow regime. As can be seen from Figure SI 2 (Section SI 3 of the SI), the absence of external mass transfer limitations has been verified, because the net rates of formation of all species remain constant at 442 and 463 K when the catalyst mass is increased from 5–10∙10−3 kg. Moreover, these results are a first indication that the plug flow regime might be valid. The results of experiments performed with varying particle diameter, to assess the occurrence of internal mass transfer limitations and verification of the plug flow regime, can be found in Figure SI 3 (Section SI 3 of the SI). At 442 K, the net rates remain constant over the range of particle diameters and, hence, internal concentration gradients can be neglected at these operating conditions. Moreover, when the catalyst particle is reduced to 0.5∙10−3 m, the ratio of the reactor inner diameter to the catalyst particle exceeds the threshold value indicating that plug flow regime is likely valid, which might imply that the plug flow assumption is also valid for the larger catalyst diameters considered in this work. At 463 K, the net rates of formation of AcOH and EtOAc remain approximately constant (|RAcOH| and REtOAc = 4.0∙10−3 mol s−1 kgcat −1), however, an increase in (the absolute value of) the net rates of formation of C2H4, H2O, EtOH and DEE is observed when the particle diameter decreases from 2 to 0.5∙10−3 m, implying that internal mass transfer gradients at this temperature do play a role and the assumption of plug flow might be invalid. As the net rate of formation of EtOAc is an order of magnitude higher compared to net rates of formation of EtOH and DEE and the majority of the experiments within this work were conducted at 442 K, the impacts of internal concentration gradients and flow maldistribution for this work are considered to be limited. 3.3 Space time effects The effects of space time on C2H4 and AcOH conversion at different temperatures and a constant pressure of 1.2 MPa and molar C2H4:AcOH:H2O:N2 feed ratio equal to 78.2:6.5:5.3:10.0 are shown in Fig. 1 A and B. Both conversions increase monotonically with space time, explained by the increasing catalyst mass at constant reactant flow rates, where the linear increase for the lower temperatures (T < 457 K) indicates the differential character of the kinetics at those temperatures. This suggests that reaction rates are only function of space time at constant operating conditions (T, P and feed composition) and are not affected by changing reactant and product concentrations. The effects of the C2H4 conversion on selectivities are shown by Fig. 1 C to E which are first-rank Delplot charts [40,41]. Within the experimental domain, the net rate of formation of EtOAc exceeds the corresponding rate of EtOH formation by an order of magnitude, while the latter is an order of magnitude higher compared to the net rate of formation of DEE, which rationalizes the dominant EtOAc selectivity and the lowest selectivity to DEE. The EtOAc selectivity increases with C2H4 conversion in the 0–1.5% range, but then decreases at higher conversions, whereas the opposite trend is observed for the selectivity to EtOH. The DEE selectivity increases monotonously with C2H4 conversion within the investigated range of operating conditions. By considering the mechanism (Scheme 1), this might indicate that at initial conversions, EtOH is formed by C2H4 hydration (r2), rationalizing its high selectivity (Fig. 1 D). When the conversions increase, more EtOAc is formed likely by direct AcOH to C2H4 addition (r1) and by esterification between AcOH and EtOH (r4) for which the latter rate likely increases with the EtOH concentration. Hence, the EtOAc selectivity (Fig. 1 C) increases at the expense of a declining EtOH selectivity (Fig. 1 D). The DEE selectivity increases with conversion, which can be rationalized by the direct EtOH to C2H4 addition (r3) and EtOH condensation (r5), where both rates are potentially increasing with the EtOH concentration. Hence, an increasing selectivity to DEE with conversion can be expected (Fig. 1 E). Moreover, the theoretical gas phase equilibrium EtOAc:EtOH:DEE product ratio equals 8.0:0.4:5.6 at 433 K, which corresponds to 57.1, 2.9 and 40.0 mol% EtOAc, EtOH and DEE selectivity, respectively. At 463 K, the molar product ratio equals 6.8:0.7:2.9, corresponding to 65.4, 6.7 and 27.9 mol% selectivity to EtOAc, EtOH and DEE respectively. Although the theoretical equilibrium composition might not be reached for the heterogeneous catalyst [42–45], e.g. there might be a higher water concentration in the pores of the catalyst compared to its concentration in the gas phase [21], these equilibrium calculations potentially indicate that a rising DEE selectivity with conversion can be expected, hence at the expense of a lower selectivity to EtOAc. The first-rank Delplot analysis reveals that EtOH is a primary product from C2H4, because the EtOH selectivity intersects the ordinate at finite value (>0 mol%) for the C2H4 conversion approaching 0%. Although the EtOAc selectivity rapidly decays when the conversion is reaching to 0%, the primary nature of EtOAc is questionable. However, experiments with only C2H4 and AcOH in the feed reveal the production of EtOAc in the absence of H2O, as a primary product [21]. The selectivity to DEE clearly declines to 0 mol% when the C2H4 conversion approaches 0%, hence DEE is not a primary product from C2H4, where its secondary nature is shown by the second-rank Delplot (Fig. 1 H). The product yields as a function of C2H4 conversion and temperature are shown by Fig. 1 I to K, where a linear increase of both EtOAc and EtOH yield and a quadratic increase of DEE yield with conversion are observed. From the considerations above, the optimal C2H4 conversion for the given molar C2H4:AcOH:H2O:N2 feed ratio (78.2:6.5:5.3:10.0) and pressure (1.2 MPa) is between 0.5% and 1.5% to yield a maximum and minimum selectivity to EtOAc and EtOH respectively. 3.4 Temperature effects At temperatures below 457 K (Fig. 1 A and B), the conversions increase linearly with space time, indicating that the experiments were likely conducted in the differential kinetic regime, where the rise of conversions with temperature is rationalized by the Arrhenius relationship. At higher temperatures, deviations from linearity are observed, most likely caused by the more significant decrease of reactant concentrations, commonly known as the conversion effect. In contrary to the differential kinetic regime, where conversions scale linearly with space time, the experiments performed at temperatures exceeding 457 K are likely performed in the integral kinetic regime. The estimated apparent activation energies of the net rates of formation and corresponding 95% confidence intervals are found in Table 5, revealing that Ea,EtOAc < Ea,EtOH < Ea,DEE, which indicates that the DEE formation is more temperature sensitive compared to the EtOH synthesis, being more affected by temperature compared to the EtOAc formation. However, at a fixed conversion, the selectivities only change with maximum 4 mol% as function of temperature, to which a slight decrease in EtOAc selectivity is observed at the expense of higher selectivities to EtOH and DEE. This can be rationalized by the net rate of formation of EtOAc, which varies between 1.2∙10−4 to 4.2∙10−3 mol s−1 kgcat −1 in the investigated range of operating conditions, and is generally an order of magnitude higher compared to the net rates of formation of EtOH and DEE. This indicates that the EtOAc formation rate is the major contribution to the C2H4 conversion and explains the high selectivity to EtOAc. Hence, a temperature change results in a change in net rate of formation of EtOAc, which remains significantly higher compared to the net rates of formation of EtOH and DEE. Hence, the change in net rate of formation of EtOAc with temperature is the dominant contribution to the change in conversions. Therefore, it can be rationalized that the selectivities and also the yields (Fig. 1 I to K) are not significantly changing with temperature at iso-conversion. Therefore, the temperature effect on selectivities is insignificant compared to the space time effect, hence, a temperature increase to compensate for a loss of catalyst activity over TOS does not compromise the selectivity to EtOAc within considered temperature domain (433–463 K). 3.5 Total pressure effects The effects of total pressure at 442 K and molar C2H4:AcOH:H2O:N2 feed ratio (78.2:6.5:5.3:10.0) on C2H4 and AcOH conversions are depicted in Fig. 2 A and B, where an apparent decrease in conversions with total pressure at a given space time is observed. The C2H4 conversions measured at 0.8, 1.0 and 1.4 MPa at (W/F0)rel = 0.41 equal 1.3%, 1.2% and 1.1% respectively and are within the 95% confidence interval at 1.2 MPa (1.2 ± 1.7∙10−1%). Similarly, the C2H4 conversion amounts to 2.8%, 2.6% and 2.4% at 0.8, 1.0 and 1.4 MPa respectively and (W/F0)rel = 0.82, which reside in the corresponding 95% confidence interval at 1.2 MPa (2.5 ± 3.6∙10−1%). Moreover, the AcOH conversion at 0.8, 1.0 and 1.4 MPa equals 14.7%, 13.9% and 12.1% respectively at (W/F0)rel = 0.41% and 30.4%, 29.2% and 26.3% respectively at (W/F0)rel = 0.82, which reside within the 95% confidence intervals, being 13.0 ± 1.9% and 27.0 ± 4.0% for the two space times respectively. Hence, although a consistent decrease in conversions with pressure is observed during different experiments, the effect of pressure on conversions is insignificant compared to the experimental error. Nonetheless, high pressures seem to be disadvantageous to achieve high conversions. Higher total pressures induce a more pronounced competitive adsorption of (condensable) oxygenates on the active sites compared to C2H4 and/or a stronger dilution of the protons and hydronium ions in the pseudo-liquid phase inside the catalyst pores leading to reduced proton or hydronium ion acid strength [21,27,32,34,46–49]. Similarly, a pressure increase leads to a reduction of maximum 1 mol% in the selectivity to EtOAc at constant conversion, which is compensated by an similar increase in EtOH selectivity (Fig. 2 C and D). The selectivity to DEE is not changing with pressure as shown in Fig. 2 E. The 95% confidence intervals of the EtOAc, EtOH and DEE selectivity at 1.2 MPa are respectively 93.0 ± 8.0∙10−1, 6.1 ± 6.9∙10−1 and 8.9∙10−1 ± 3.6∙10−1 mol% at (W/F0)rel = 0.41 and respectively 91.4 ± 7.9∙10−1, 6.5 ± 7.3∙10−1 and 2.1 ± 8.7∙10−1 mol% at (W/F0)rel = 0.82, indicating that all selectivities at different pressures are within these intervals, hence, implying that the changes in selectivity with pressure are also insignificant compared to the experimental error. As seen in Table 5, all net rates have a negative order in pressure, where the difference in dependence may rationalize the effect of the pressure on the selectivities as a result of variations in active site coverages or compositional changes inside the catalyst pores. Considering the effect of pressure on kinetics at the constant temperature and molar feed ratio a reactor should be operated at a low pressure to benefit both conversions and selectivity towards the main EtOAc product. 3.6 Reactant feed concentration effects The effects of the ethylene mole fraction in the feed on conversions at 442 K, 1.2 MPa with 6.5 mol% AcOH and 5.3 mol% H2O in the feed are presented in Fig. 3, 1A and 1B, where an increase in the C2H4 mole fraction from 48.2 to 85.2 mol% leads to a slight increase in its conversion (less than 0.5 mol%) unlike a significant increase in AcOH conversion (15–31%). This effect is rationalized by the positive partial reaction order with respect to C2H4 of the involved reactions (Table 5), which may indicate a weak C2H4 adsorption [34]. Hence, the increasing conversions with the feed mole fraction is rationalized by the increase in amount of C2H4 adsorbed on the catalyst, leading to an increase in protonation rate, likely the rate limiting reaction step [23]. An increase in C2H4 feed fraction results in an insignificant reduction (< 0.5 mol%) in EtOAc selectivity at the expense of a slightly higher EtOH selectivity (Figs. 3, 1C and 1D), explained by the similar dependence of the net rates of formation of EtOAc and EtOH on C2H4 feed fraction. A more pronounced dependence is again observed in the net rate of formation of DEE, however, no significant effect on the selectivity to DEE is observed (Figs. 3, 1E). When the AcOH feed fraction is increased from 2.5 to 10.5 mol% at 442 K, 1.2 MPa with 78.2 mol% C2H4 and 5.3 mol% H2O in the feed, a reduction in both C2H4 and AcOH conversion, of respectively 0.4% and 26%, is observed (Figs. 3, 2A and 2B). This is reflected by the negative partial reaction orders in yAcOH 0 of all net rates in Table 5, where the increase in FAcOH 0 with AcOH feed concentration also contributes to the reduction in AcOH conversion. The decrease in conversions can be explained by a more pronounced coverage of the active sites with the AcOH feed concentration, resulting in a reduction of the adsorption of other reacting species, e.g. C2H4. Moreover, a more pronounced condensation of AcOH in the pores can lead to a dilution of protons or hydronium ions, resulting in reduced acid strength compared to undiluted or dehydrated protons [27]. A reduction in conversion with AcOH concentration was observed in the liquid phase esterification of AcOH and propanol on phosphotungstic acid supported on montmorillonite K10, which was attributed to the dilution of propanol isomers [50]. A similar effect was also observed in the liquid phase esterification between AcOH and sec-butanol on phosphotungstic acid supported on montmorillonite clay, where the effect was attributed to leaching of the active phase from the catalyst [51]. Although the AcOH feed fraction is disadvantageous to yield high conversions, it benefits the EtOAc selectivity (+16 mol%) concomitant to significant reductions in both EtOH (−10 mol%) and DEE (−6 mol%) selectivities at equal conversion (Figs. 3, 2C to 2E). This is rationalized by the stronger dependence of the net rates of formation of EtOH and DEE on AcOH feed fraction compared to the net rate of formation of EtOAc (Table 5), which is possibly explained by AcOH being an essential reactant for EtOAc synthesis, therefore partially compensating the decreasing effect of AcOH on reaction rates r1 and/or r4 (Scheme 1). The H2O feed concentration drastically impacts on both conversions and selectivity to EtOAc (Figs. 3, 3A to 3C). An increase of H2O from 3.3 to 9.3 mol% at 442 K, 1.2 MPa with 78.2 mol% C2H4 and 6.5 mol% AcOH in the feed results in a maximum reduction in C2H4 conversion (4.2–1.1%) and AcOH conversion (46–12%). Similarly to the effect of the AcOH feed fraction, the net rates have a negative partial reaction order in the H2O feed fraction (Table 5). Similar decreasing reaction rates with H2O were reported for the dehydration of EtOH on a phosphotungstic acid catalyst, propylene hydration on phosphotungstic acid catalyst, where the decreasing reaction rates were attributed to formation of poly-hydrated hydroxonium ions, which possess lower acid strength compared to dehydrated protons [24,25,27,34]. However, the reductions in reaction rates may also be explained by competitive adsorption of H2O and other species on active sites. An increase in H2O fraction is also disadvantageous to establish a high EtOAc selectivity, which decreases with maximum 5–10 mol% at identical C2H4 conversion, whereas the EtOH selectivity increases with an equal amount (Figs. 3, 3C to 3D), possibly explained by the less pronounced dependence of the net rate of formation of EtOH on the H2O feed fraction compared to the net rate of formation of EtOAc. This might be rationalized by H2O being a reactant in the net rate of formation of EtOH by either C2H4 hydration or EtOAc hydrolysis. Although the DEE formation is most strongly affected by the H2O feed fraction, no effect on its selectivity is observed (Figs. 3, 3E). Combining the observations and discussions above, it seems advantageous to operate a reactor at high C2H4 concentrations to reach high AcOH conversions without compromising the EtOAc selectivity. The AcOH feed fraction tremendously affects conversions, both C2H4 and AcOH, but allows enhancing the EtOAc selectivity at the expense of both the EtOH and DEE selectivity. Therefore, an optimum feed concentration should be identified. Increasing the H2O feed concentrations is disadvantageous for both conversions and selectivity to EtOAc, therefore the water concentration should be kept low. However, the effects of the reactants feed concentrations on catalyst deactivation must be considered to find the optimal feed composition, which is out of the scope of this work. 3.7 Comparison of the space time, temperature, pressure and reactant feed concentration effects When comparing the effects of space time, temperature, pressure and the reactant feed concentrations on conversions and selectivities, as elaborated in Sections 3.3 to 3.6 and shown by Figs. 1 to 3, it is clear that the C2H4 and AcOH conversions are primarily affected by space time, temperature and H2O concentration in the feed within the experimental domain. Hence, these operating conditions are the dominant levers to tune the conversions, while the pressure, C2H4 and AcOH feed concentrations are of secondary importance to change the conversions. When considering the selectivities to EtAc, EtOH and DEE within the experimental domain, the space time, AcOH and H2O feed concentrations are of primary importance to tailor the selectivities, whereas the temperature, pressure and C2H4 concentration in the feed have little effect on the selectivities. These findings suggest that the space time should be well chosen in terms of optimizing both the conversions and selectivities, whereas the AcOH and H2O feed concentrations should a priori be set towards the desired selectivities. Furthermore, a temperature increase to elevate the conversions or to compensate for a loss of catalyst activity, does not significantly affect the selectivities. Given the experimental results, the pressure and C2H4 concentration in the feed are secondary levers to tailor conversions and selectivities and might therefore be tuned as function of the production plants’ design, operating costs, catalyst deactivation rates, etc. However, as mentioned in Section 3.6, the catalyst deactivation must be considered as well to find the optimal reaction feed composition, which is not scope of this work. 3.8 Apparent relationships between the net rates of formation of the products Throughout the datasets several operating conditions were systematically varied, allowing to identify apparent relationships between the net rates of formation. In Fig. 4, the net rate of formation of EtOAc is presented as a function of the net rate of formation of EtOH and T, P and feed composition at (W/F0)rel = 0.41 and 0.82, for which a linear relationship between both rates is observed. Similarly, a quadratic relationship between the net formation rates of DEE and EtOH as a function of the operating conditions can be observed from Fig. 5. The linear relationship between the net formation rates of EtOAc and EtOH suggests that EtOH and EtOAc are rapidly interconverted by esterification or EtOAc hydrolysis (r4 on Scheme 1). This can be rationalized by the polar nature of EtOH, AcOH, EtOAc and H2O and their relatively small sizes, suggesting that the esterification and hydrolysis reactions can occur in the bulk of the STA particles inside the pores of the catalyst, hence ‘bulk protons’ are available for catalysis [32]. Therefore, higher rates for the esterification and hydrolysis are expected compared to reactions involving hydrocarbons such as C2H4, which were reported to proceed via surface-type catalysis [12,52]. Hence the rate of reaction r4 is likely higher than r1 and r2 (Scheme 1), rationalizing the linear relationship between the net rates of formation of EtOAc and EtOH. A strong deviation from this linear relationship is seen in Fig. 4 D at which the reduction in yAcOH 0 from 10.5 to 2.5 mol% results in a decrease in the net rate of formation of EtOAc compared to an increase in the net rate of formation of EtOH. When the H2O concentration in the feed is lowered from 9.3 to 3.3 mol% at a relative space time equal to 0.41 (Fig. 4 E), the net rate of formation of EtOAc increases more than proportionally compared to the net rate of formation of EtOH, which can be explained by EtOAc being also formed by direct addition of AcOH to C2H4, indicating the primary nature of the product. A quadratic relationship is observed between the net rates of formation of EtOH and DEE (Fig. 5), suggesting that the net rate of formation of DEE quadratically depends on the EtOH concentration within the investigated range of operating conditions. As with the esterification between AcOH and EtOH and EtOAc hydrolysis, the EtOH dehydration to DEE and DEE hydrolysis can proceed in the bulk of heteropoly acids and are therefore faster compared to surface reactions, such as the direct addition of EtOH to C2H4 [52]. Hence, reaction r5 is likely faster compared to r3 (Scheme 1) and the quadratic dependence of the EtOH dehydration rate on EtOH concentration was described in the literature as a result of the formation of a protonated EtOH dimer, i.e. (C2H5OH)2H+, oligomers or the adsorption of EtOH on two different active sites prior to dehydration [20,22,24,32,53]. Hence, the observed quadratic relationship between the net rates of formation of EtOH and DEE can be understood. The linear and quadratic relationships are also reflected in the product yields as function of the C2H4 conversion, which are presented by Fig. 1 I to K, where both the EtOAc and EtOH yields scale linearly with C2H4 conversion and where the DEE yield scales quadratically with conversion. As mentioned before, the net rate of formation of EtOAc is an order of magnitude higher compared to the net rates of formation of EtOH and DEE, hence providing the most pronounced contribution to the C2H4 conversion and therefore rationalizing the linear relationship between EtOAc yield and conversion. Because the net rates of formation of EtOAc and EtOH scale linearly with each other, a linear relationship between the EtOH yield and C2H4 conversion can be rationalized. Similarly, the quadratic relationship between net rates of formation of DEE and EtOH explain the quadratic relationship between DEE yield and C2H4 conversion. 4 Conclusions The kinetics of the ethyl acetate synthesis via direct addition of acetic acid to ethylene on an industrial silicotungstic acid catalyst have been investigated at different space times and operating conditions, i.e. temperature, pressure and reactant concentrations. Conversions, selectivities towards the major products, being ethyl acetate, ethanol and diethyl ether, and net rates of formation have been determined. An increase in total pressure or acetic acid and water feed concentrations are found to reduce conversions and rates, likely as a result of a more competitive adsorption of these components and other oxygenates compared to ethylene or a stronger dilution of the protons and hydronium ions of the silicotungstic acid. An increase in temperature and ethylene feed fraction enhance conversions, rationalized by the Arrhenius relationship and a rise in adsorption of the reactant on the catalyst respectively. Given the experimental results, the space time, temperature and water feed concentration are the dominant levers to adjust conversions, whereas the pressure, ethylene and acetic acid concentrations in the feed are of secondary importance. Within the investigated range of operating conditions, it was shown that the apparent activation energy of the net rate of formation of ethyl acetate is lower compared to the net rates of formation of ethanol and diethyl ether, where the former component has the highest net rate of formation, rationalizing its dominant selectivity. Selectivities are mainly affected by conversions, where an increase in conversion yields a maximum ethyl acetate selectivity and subsequently reduces at higher conversions. The opposite trend is observed for the ethanol selectivity, while the diethyl ether selectivity is monotonously increasing with conversion. The effects of conversions on selectivities are rationalized by considering the reactions in the mechanism and theoretical gas phase equilibrium. Among the operating conditions, temperature, pressure as well as ethylene concentration in the feed barely affect selectivity. A rise in acetic acid feed fraction increases the ethyl acetate selectivity, rationalized by a reduction in net rates of formation of ethanol and diethyl, where the net rate of formation of ethyl acetate is not affected. Similarly, an increase in water concentration in the feed leads to reduction of the net rates of formation, however, less pronounced for the net rate of formation of ethanol and therefore explaining the reduction in ethyl acetate selectivity with water concentration in the feed. Within the experimental domain, the selectivities are primarily affected by space time, acetic acid and water feed concentrations, while varying the temperature, pressure and ethylene concentration in the feed do not drastically change the selectivities. In the present work, the effects of the operating conditions on the kinetics of the ethyl acetate by direct additions reaction have been elaborated. The experimental data and observed trends form the basis for the future development of a kinetic model, which can serve for optimization of industrial production plants and thereby reduce costs, waste and impact on environment and climate. coredata.dc:description: The kinetics of the ethyl acetate synthesis by direct addition of acetic acid to ethylene on an industrial silicotungstic acid catalyst have been acquired experimentally by systematically varying the operating conditions. This is essential to assess the effects of the operating conditions on reactant conversions, selectivity towards the main product ethyl acetate and side products, i.e. ethanol and diethyl ether. Conversions benefit from increasing reaction temperature and ethylene concentration and from reducing pressure, acetic acid and water concentrations. Higher acetic acid and lower water concentrations are advantageous for the ethyl acetate selectivity, which is not altered by temperature, pressure and ethylene concentration. Present work is the first publication of experimental kinetics data of this reaction on an industrial catalyst, which is essential to provide qualitative insights in the reaction kinetics, improve understanding and, hence, serve the optimization and innovation of ethyl acetate production plants that apply the direct addition technology.
coredata.dc:title: Ethyl acetate synthesis by direct addition of acetic acid to ethylene on a silicotungstic acid catalyst: Experimental assessment of the kinetics
